title: 108_s2790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" and involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows the Secretary of the Interior to issue a certificate of bidding rights to holders of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to issue a certificate of bidding rights to holders of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications, relinquishing all associated rights upon issuance. The withdrawn coal preference lease applications will be effective upon issuance of the certificate of bidding rights under section 4(a)(2). No further adjudication by the Secretary is required for these withdrawals and issuances. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn coal preference right lease applications is determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary establishes a panel within 30 days of the Act's enactment to determine the fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications. The panel consists of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary. The panel for determining the fair market value of coal reserves consists of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the holder of the preference right lease application, and the Governor of the State of New Mexico. The Secretary will contract with a qualified coal reserve appraiser to assist the panel. The panel for determining the fair market value of coal reserves in New Mexico will include 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the lease applicant, and the Governor. A qualified coal reserve appraiser will assist the panel in valuing the coal reserve, with the option to supplement information as needed. The panel must make a determination within 75 days of its establishment. The panel, within 75 days of establishment, will submit to the Secretary its determination on the fair market value of a coal reserve from any withdrawn lease application. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application, to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 and facilitate land consolidation. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application, to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 and facilitate land consolidation. The Secretary is required to select land in New Mexico under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 and issue a certificate of bidding rights based on fair market value for mineral development in northwest New Mexico. The duties of the Secretary in this regard are considered nondiscretionary and enforceable in a mandamus proceeding. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be transferred in whole or in part and used as a monetary credit. The Secretary may establish procedures for transfer and accounting of holders and their balances. The certificate of bidding rights can be used as a monetary credit against payments to the Secretary for Federal coal leases. The certificate of bidding rights can be used as a monetary credit against payments for Federal coal leases under the Mineral Leasing Act. Holders of the certificate of bidding rights can apply it to 50% of the payment obligation under a Federal coal lease, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or cash equivalent. Payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by holders of a certificate of bidding rights is treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act. 50% of the payment is distributed to the State where the lease is located. 50% of the payment for a Federal coal lease obligation is distributed to the State where the lease is located, while the remaining 50% is subject to redistribution to the Reclamation and Miscellaneous Receipts accounts in the Treasury.
